Spooky fun for children at Suffolk Libraries this half-term

Written by Alice Violett · Published Oct 21, 2016

Libraries all over Suffolk are putting on fun activities for children next week to celebrate Halloween.

Crafts

  • Haverhill Library are holding a special ’Boo’ book folding session for children on Friday 28 October. Book folding gives old books a new, decorative purpose, as the pages are reshaped to form pictures or patterns. If that sounds like something you’d like to try yourself, Haverhill are holding a book folding session for adults on Saturday 5 November.

  • At Gainsborough Library on Saturday 29 October and Sunday 30 October, you can carve pumpkins and make Halloween decorations. Pumpkin numbers are limited, though, so be sure to get there before they run out.

There are also Halloween-themed craft sessions at:

  • Gainsborough Library on Monday 24 October.

  • Halesworth Library on Wednesday 26 October

  • Great Cornard Library on Friday 28 October.

  • Oulton Broad Library on Sunday 30 October.

Why not bring your child to the library to make some spooky decorations for your home?

Stories

  • Mildenhall Library are holding special Stories in the Dark sessions for 2-5 year-olds at 11am, 12pm and 2pm on Friday 28 October. 2015 Suffolk Skald of the year Marion Leeper will be in the magic tent providing a multi-sensory experience as she explains who stole the darkness, why the sun and moon are high and dry in the sky, and how three monkeys came to be in a canoe. Be sure to book in advance, as only 15 people can fit in this tiny theatre!

  • Haverhill Library are encouraging children to dress up for their Halloween-themed storytelling session on Tuesday 25 October, and providing milk and cookies.

  • The half-term crafts sessions at Bury St Edmunds which run from 9am to 1pm each day from Monday 24 October to Saturday 29 October combine storytelling, crafts, and, intriguingly, an unlucky dip!

Other libraries whose Halloween sessions feature a mixture of stories, crafts and other activities are:

  • Leiston Library on Tuesday 25 October.

  • Chantry Library on Thursday 27 October.

  • Lowestoft Library on Saturday 29 October.

Nature

Children also have the opportunity to meet birds and mini-beasts at some of our libraries during half-term.

  • The Bird of Prey Centre at Stonham Barns is holding a session at Ipswich Library on Tuesday 25 October, offering children the opportunity to see and learn out about their majestic creatures. There will also be crafts sessions at the library on the same day.

  • Suffolk Owl Sanctuary, are also visiting us from Stonham Barns. They’re at Stowmarket Library on Wednesday 26 October. Children can meet a falconer and owls from the sanctuary, and make an owl or Halloween item courtesy of the Friends of Stowmarket Library.

  • Also on Wednesday 26 October, butterflies of Britain are at Lowestoft Library for Halloween-themed mini-beast crafts, activities and fun. We recommend that you book in advance.

  • Although there won’t be any animals present, Kessingland Library’s Fishy Crafts and Fishy Tales session on Friday 28 October is worth a visit. In celebration of the area’s heritage, children will hear fish-themed stories and make fish-themed crafts.

Something a bit different

  • On the spooky/mystical theme, Hadleigh Library are holding what looks to be a fantastic Harry Potter-themed night on Tuesday 25 October. For £5 your child can make their own wand and a Hogwarts school hat, and enjoy a Harry Potter-themed area with props. There’s also a free Harry Potter creature competition and optional extras; see the event page for full details.

  • Children in Southwold have the opportunity to partake in activities led by Catherine Pearson, author of Southwold-based children’s book The Sole Bay Railway. This sounds like a really exciting book, so this event is bound to be special.

Hopefully, with all these activities, you won’t have to hear the dreaded strains of ‘I’m bored!’.
